current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To provide high-quality public charter
		  school options for students by enabling such public charter schools to expand
		  and replicate.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
All Students Achieving through Reform
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: by redesignating

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5209

text.#text: by inserting after

It is the purpose of this section to
				support State efforts to expand and replicate high-quality public charter
				schools to enable such schools to serve additional students, with a priority to
				serve those students who attend identified schools or schools with a low
				graduation rate.

is under the jurisdiction of, or plans to

ensures that all public charter schools
				(including such schools served by a local educational agency and such schools
				considered to be a local educational agency under State law) receive, in a
				timely manner, the Federal, State, and local funds to which such schools are
				entitled under applicable law;

provides funding (such as capital aid
				distributed through a formula or access to revenue generated bonds, and
				including funding for school facilities) on a per-pupil basis to public charter
				schools commensurate with the amount of funding (including funding for school
				facilities) provided to traditional public schools;

authorizes or
				allows public charter schools to serve as school food authorities;

ensures that each public charter school in
				the State—

has a high degree of autonomy over the
				public charter school’s budget and expenditures;

has a written performance contract with an
				authorized public chartering agency that ensures that the school has an
				independent governing board with a high degree of autonomy; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5210/ss:e

in the case of an eligible public charter

has an appeals process for the denial of an

provides that an authorized public

				a public charter school pursuant to such State law;

allows any public charter school to be a
				local educational agency in accordance with State law;

ensures that each authorized public
				chartering agency in the State submits annual reports to the State educational
				agency, and makes such reports available to the public, on the performance of

				reports shall include—

the authorized public chartering agency’s
				policies for authorizing or approving public charter schools, including how

financial plan and policies, including
				financial controls and audit requirements;

plan for identifying and successfully (in

capacity and capability to successfully
				launch and subsequently operate a public charter school, including the

the authorized public chartering agency’s
				policies for renewing, not renewing, and revoking a public charter school's

a process for reviewing and evaluating the

any other necessary policies to ensure

text.#text: In awarding grants under this section, the

An eligible entity receiving a grant under
				this section shall use the grant funds for the following:

An eligible entity shall award subgrants,
				in such amount as the eligible entity determines is appropriate, to eligible
				public charter schools to replicate or expand such schools.

An eligible public charter school desiring
				to receive a subgrant under this subsection shall submit an application to the
				eligible entity at such time, in such manner, and containing such information
				as the eligible entity may require.

An eligible public charter school receiving
				a subgrant under this subsection shall use the subgrant funds to provide for an
				increase in the school’s enrollment of students through the replication or
				expansion of the school, which may include use of funds to—

pay costs associated with hiring additional
				teachers to serve additional students;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
), as long as the eligible public charter school
				demonstrates to the eligible entity, in the application required under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1116/ss:b/p:11
Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5210/ss:e/p:1/sp:B

text.#text:
provide transportation to additional
				students to and from the school (including providing transportation to students
				who transfer to the school under a cooperative agreement established under

purchase instructional materials, implement
				teacher and principal professional development programs, and hire additional
				non-teaching staff; and

support any necessary activities associated
				with the school carrying out the purposes of this section, including data
				collection and management.

In awarding subgrants under this
				subsection, an eligible entity shall give priority to an eligible public
				charter school that—

for tested grades and subjects, by a

for non-tested grades and subjects,
				alternative measures of student learning and performance, such as student
				scores on pretests and end-of-course tests, student performance on English
				language proficiency assessments; and other measures of student achievement
				that are rigorous and comparable across classrooms; and

the management and leadership necessary to
				overcome initial start-up problems and establish a thriving, financially viable
				charter school.

A subgrant under this subsection shall be
				awarded for a period of not more than 3 years, except that an eligible public
				charter school receiving a subgrant under this subsection may, at the
				discretion of the eligible entity, continue to expend subgrant funds after the
				end of the subgrant period.

Funds received under this section and

				or in other similarly low-risk securities.
